Whilst I hold Rocky I and Rocky II as the best in the saga Rocky V for me easily sweeps third spot. People expected something different to what this movie actually produced and I get the feeling some people would have rather had a cheesy boxing film like Rocky III and Rocky IV and have Rocky take on an ultimately unbelievable opponent. Well sorry, not here. I like this heart filled and story oriented film, unlike Rocky III and Rocky IV this film isn't primarily about boxing, it's about Rocky trying to pass on his legacy to a young boxer who eventually stabs him in the back.

In training this young boxer Rocky neglects his family and starts to forget what means the most to him. Perhaps he feels that Tommy Gunn is the only way to bring the money and the flash lifestyle back to him and his family, but by the end of the film you will know that the only thing which ever mattered to Rocky was his family and his own self respect. This trumps Rocky III and Rocky IV in the fact that it had an emotional impact, which both of those films lacked. Mickey's and Apollo's deaths were played out within two or three scenes before Rocky is back with the cheesy music preparing to take on an unbelievable opponent in those films, you practically forget that those characters died. Where as in Rocky V after losing his money and then being convinced by Adrian not to fight (remember this line "I don't care about the money, it's you" or something similar?) that scene right there had an emotional impact. That impact played out for several scenes including the epic flashback scene in the old gym with Mick, which was probably the second most emotional scene in the entire saga after Rocky reading to Adrian whilst she is in a coma. With Rocky low on his chips, he trains an upcoming fighter who quickly replicates Rocky's style and hunger in the ring however eventually shows that he doesn't have Rocky's heart when he leaves Rocky for a selfish promoter weho promises Tommy fame. The film deals with what was a big issue in boxing and that is corruption.

With a damaged brain and haunted by visions of his previous fights Rocky is in no shape to fight but the ruthless Tommy Gunn persists and eventually knocks down Rocky's closest friend Paulie, to which Rocky can take no more, demanding Gunn meets him outside for the biggest and most emotional fight in the saga.

Easily laying Gunn down in the first round Rocky claims his anguish at what Gunn had done to him stating that he and Gunn were suppose to be like "Brothers", hurt; Rocky makes his way back but Gunn isn't finished he sneaks up behind Rocky and attacks him cheaply in the street. Rocky dazed and confused takes Gunn's best punches, each one triggering flash backs to the powerful Russian beating Rocky. Eventually Rocky is put to the floor and Gunn cockily strides off with his promoter.

BUT Rocky isn't down yet, his last inspiration comes in the form of a vision of Mickey who proclaims "He's no machine, I didn't hear no bell! GET UP YOU SON OF A B|TCH! COS MICKEY LOVES YA", no Rocky fan can deny that this line sends a tingling down their spine and a sparkle in their eye as Rocky rises and shouts to Gunn "Hey Tommy! I didn't hear no bell! One more round", Gunn obliges whilst his promoter who doesn't believe Gunn has what it takes to beat Rocky in a street fight shouts "You lose you're finished!". So this is it Rocky and Gunn exchange blows before Adrian and Robert arrive at street side to offer their support, when it looks like Rocky is losing their cries of support spur him on. Add to this the awesome music and you really have an epic battle.

review_title: This is the most unique of all the "Rocky" films. Does that make it good or bad?
review_detailed_main: "Rocky V" (1990), this movie is generally overlooked by most people. I just have to ask, why? Not only is this the most unique film of the entire series, it also has the darkest storyline. Which, to be honest, makes it all the more exciting to watch! "Rocky V" has a perfect story, perfect acting, perfect sets/locations, perfect special effects, and of course a perfect soundtrack to tie it together. The story is that Rocky is forced to retire from boxing due to brain damage from previous boxing matches, especially from his fight against Ivan Drago. That's certainly a different turn in the series. Five movies in, it was the perfect time for a twist like this. Rocky takes over Mickey's gym and agrees to train a boxer named Tommy Gunn. That causes Rocky's son, Robert, to fall into the wrong crowd and then eventually withdraw himself from the family. Another unique thing about the plot of this movie is that the final fight isn't a boxing match, it's a street fight. That was a neat change of pace, because it's the only film of the series without a boxing match with Rocky himself! Talk about a dilemma, the storyline keeps you invested all the way through from beginning to end, which is what a perfect plot should do. As for the acting, it's stellar as usual from all the actors and actresses. We have a couple of new characters in this film; Tommy Gunn, played by Tommy Morrison and George Washington Duke, played by Richard Gant. They play the main villains in this movie and their performances are great. Both actors really make you personally hate their characters, which results in their eventual comeuppances being all the more satisfying. Of course, Sylvester Stallone is the shining star once again. One cool thing to point out, Rocky's son is played by Sylvester Stallone's actual son, Sage Stallone (R.I.P.) in the "Rocky" films, with the exception of the movie, "Rocky Balboa" (2006). His presence adds a whole new depth of chemistry to the characters! All of the sets/locations are perfect, they set the tone for the story and also give this movie a great atmosphere. As far as special effects go, there aren't that many. But, all that are utilized are perfect and still hold up to this day. Finally, the soundtrack composed by Bill Conti is nothing short of a masterpiece. Bill Conti is one of my top 10 all-time favorite film score composers, and this soundtrack is nothing short of phenomenal. This whole film score is fantastic, my personal favorite part of the soundtrack in this movie is the music during the final fight. It never fails to give an adrenaline rush! "Rocky V" is such an unfairly overlooked movie. It definitely deserves more praise than it usually gets. But, I'm not a common person who mirrors someone else's opinions, I'm always honest with my reviews. "Rocky V" is an excellent film! I can watch it over and over again and never get bored with it. Of course, I give this film 5 out of 5 stars on my scale, which equates to 10 out of 10 IMDB stars. If you haven't seen "Rocky V", what are you waiting for? Go and see it today. Or else, George Washington Duke will sue you!

review_title: Why all the haters??! very good movie and highly underrated.

review_detailed_main: All right, this ain't no Citizen Kane and won't be getting academy awards in a million years, but this is a really good movie. This breaks from the traditional Rocky formula and bring us to a more down to earth depiction of the life of an aging athlete. There is a lot of Family drama, heart warming scenes and also some good old life lessons. If they wanted to make a soulless sequel, they just had to invent another big bad rival to challenge Rocky in a big climax for the tittle. However, they instead took the risk to make something different, and (even though that by itself doesn't make a great movie), in my opinion, the result was something that enriched the character and story of the previous films. It makes them feel more real. As stated before, it won't bring home any awards (although that is hardly to be expected for the fourth sequel of a saga), but it's really fun, entretaining and made with a lot of heart. I don't really know what else to expect from a movie.

review_title: Skip It! It Doesn't Even Feel Like A Rocky Movie!
Rocky sequel that should've been the finale
I loved this movie when it came out
A Raw, Emotional Return to Rocky's Roots
review_detailed_main:
"Rocky V" (1990) is a unique and introspective chapter in the Rocky series, offering a much-needed return to the gritty realism and personal stakes that made the original film so compelling. Directed by John G. Avildsen, the fifth installment in the saga takes Rocky Balboa (Sylvester Stallone) out of the ring and places him back into a more grounded, real-world setting, dealing with the aftermath of his boxing career and the challenges of life after the spotlight.

In this film, Rocky is forced to confront not only his physical limitations but also his role as a father and mentor. His relationship with his son, played by Sage Stallone, provides some of the film's most poignant and emotional moments. The tension between their differing views on life and the impact of Rocky's legacy adds depth and complexity to the story, shifting the focus from grandiose boxing matches to a more personal and relatable struggle.

While Rocky V doesn't have the same high-octane energy of its predecessors, it compensates with a deeply emotional narrative. The film explores themes of family, loss, and redemption, with Rocky attempting to rebuild his life after losing his fortune and his health. The film's final showdown, a street fight with Tommy Gunn (played by real-life boxer Tommy Morrison), is a fitting and symbolic conclusion to the saga, emphasizing that the real battle is not always fought in the ring.

What sets "Rocky V" apart is its raw, unpolished tone, which contrasts with the more polished, over-the-top spectacle of "Rocky IV." While it may not be as universally beloved, the film stands as a testament to Rocky's resilience in the face of personal adversity. With a strong emotional core and a focus on the human side of its legendary protagonist, "Rocky V" is an underrated and thought-provoking entry that provides a powerful conclusion to the character's journey before the series reinvents itself in later installments.

review_title: It had to come an end, I'll never forget
review_detailed_main:
So, Rocky V is definitely the black sheep of the series, but it has its moments if you're a fan of the character. The story tries to shake things up by taking Rocky back to his roots in Philly after he loses his fortune and his physical health following his brutal fight with Ivan Drago in Rocky IV. This time, instead of Rocky in the ring, he's in the corner as a trainer to a young, ambitious boxer named Tommy Gunn. But things go south when Tommy's ego takes over, and he betrays Rocky, leading to a showdown in the streets rather than the ring.

What's interesting in this one is how it deals with Rocky as a person who's lost everything and is struggling to reconnect with his family, especially his son. It's rawer and tries to bring Rocky down to earth after the crazy, larger-than-life battles of the earlier films. Unfortunately, though, it's missing some of the charm and grit that made the earlier movies so great. Rocky's journey from glory to struggles feels a bit forced, and the lack of an actual boxing match left some fans wanting more.

Still, Rocky V has that Stallone heart and nostalgia, and it offers a real attempt at depth in Rocky's character, showing a side of him as he tries to be a mentor and a father. It's not the fan-favorite, but if you love the series, it's worth watching just to see Rocky in a new light.

In my humble opinion this film, like all the other Rocky films, has heart and emotion and because it does I truly appreciate it for those values alone.

Folks say it's, "cheesy" and "overrated" but it gives you the opportunity to see how you can be on top of the World one moment and absolutely down on your luck the next moment.

People say it's, "the ebbs and flows of life..." and that's true in many cases, but with Rocky 5 it's the Balboa Family on top of the World and then back in the old South Philly neighborhood again with nothing but Mickey's Boxing Gym to show for it.

An example for sure!
